  35  LOCK TABLES `avl_content_description` WRITE;
  36  INSERT INTO `avl_content_description` (`content_id`, `content_description`) VALUES (267,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Introduction&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nWithin electrical engineering, a DC circuit (Direct Current circuit) is an electrical circuit that consists of any combination of constant voltage sources, constant current sources, and resistors. In this case, the circuit voltages and currents are constant, i.e., independent of time. More technically, a DC circuit has no memory. That is, a particular circuit voltage or current does not depend on the past value of any circuit voltage or current. This implies that the system of equations that represent a DC circuit do not involve integrals or derivatives.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn electronics, it is common to refer to a circuit that is powered by a DC voltage source such as a battery or the output of a DC power supply as a DC circuit even though what is meant is that the circuit is DC powered.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Use of DC Circuit Simulation Kit&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIt is a flash based simulation of DC electrical circuits. Users can build circuits of their choice using components like resistors, batteries, wires, switches and bulbs and they can take the voltage and current readings across any points using a voltmeter, ammeters and a non-contact ammeter. The voltage and resistance values of different components like resistors bulbs and batteries can be varied and set to the de sired value. Users can also choose whether or not to have a resistance for connecting wires.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe simulation covers all the aspects of DC circuits and can be used as a simulator for lab based electrical experiments as well as a teaching aid in explaining various concepts like the ohms law, Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s law, etc.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe objectives of the tool include:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Building DC circuits and making measurements.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Verifying Ohm&amp;rsquo;s law&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Verifying parallel and series connections.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Verifying Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s voltage and current law.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Designing a current source of specified values for a particular circuit.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Verifying Thevenin&amp;rsquo;s theorem.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Verifying Norton&amp;rsquo;s theorem.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Concepts&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Ohm&amp;rsquo;s Law:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nOhm&#039;s law applies to electrical circuits; it states that the current through a conductor between two points is directly proportional to the potential difference or voltage across the two points, and inversely proportional to the resistance between them. The mathematical equation that describes this relationship is:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;45&quot; width=&quot;60&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation2.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;Series and Parallel Connections&lt;/strong&gt;:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;In electronics, components of an electronic circuit can be connected in series or in parallel.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;266&quot; width=&quot;336&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation3.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;Components connected in series are connected along a single path, so the same current flows through all of the components. Components connected in parallel are connected so the same voltage is applied to each component.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nA circuit composed solely of components connected in series is known as a series circuit; likewise, one connected completely in parallel is known as a parallel circuit.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s Laws:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;strong&gt;Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s Current Law&lt;/strong&gt;: This law is also called Kirchhoff&#039;s point rule, Kirchhoff&#039;s junction rule (or nodal rule), and Kirchhoff&#039;s first rule. It implies that, &amp;rsquo;At any point in an electrical circuit that does not represent a capacitor plate, the sum of currents flowing towards that point is equal to the sum &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;109&quot; width=&quot;132&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation4.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;of currents flowing away from that point&amp;rsquo;.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &lt;strong&gt;Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s Voltage Law&lt;/strong&gt;: This law is also called Kirchhoff&#039;s second law, Kirchhoff&#039;s loop (or mesh) rule, and Kirchhoff&#039;s second rule and states that &amp;lsquo;The directed sum of the electrical potential differences around any closed circuit must be zero&amp;rsquo;. It can be represented as:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;53&quot; width=&quot;87&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation5.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;Here, n is the total number of voltages measured.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Modified Nodal Analysis&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn Electrical Engineering Modified Nodal Analysis or MNA is an extension of the nodal analysis method that not only determines the circuit&#039;s node voltages (as in the classical nodal analysis), but also some branch currents.The MNA uses the element&#039;s Branch Constitutive Equations or BCE Lecture , i.e., their voltage - current characteristic and the Kirchhoff&#039;s circuit laws. The method is done in four steps, but it can be reduced to three.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n1. Write the KCL of the circuit. At each node of an electric circuit one writes the currents coming in and out of the node. Take care however in the MNA the current of the independent voltage sources is taken from the &amp;quot;plus&amp;quot; to the &amp;quot;minus&amp;quot;. See Figure 1. Also note that the right hand side of each equation is always equal to zero. So that the branch currents that come inside the node are given a negative sign, whereas the branch currents coming out are given a positive sign.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. Use the BCE in terms of the node voltages of the circuit to eliminate as many branch currents as possible. Writing the BCE&#039;s in terms of the node voltages saves one step. If the BCE&#039;s were written in terms of the branch voltages, one more step, i.e., replacing the branches voltages for the node ones, would be necessary. In this article the letter &amp;quot;e&amp;quot; is use to name the node voltages, while the letter &amp;quot;v&amp;quot; is used to name the branch voltages.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n3. Finally, write down the unused equations.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Norton&#039;s theorem&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nNorton&#039;s theorem for electrical networks states that any collection of voltage sources, current sources, and resistors with two terminals is electrically equivalent to an ideal current source, I, in parallel with a single resistor, R. For single-frequency AC systems the theorem can also be applied to general impedances, not just resistors. The Norton equivalent is used to represent any network of linear sources and impedances, at a given frequency. The circuit consists of an ideal current source in parallel with an ideal impedance (or resistor for non-reactive circuits). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;134&quot; width=&quot;149&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation6.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;131&quot; width=&quot;147&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation7.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;132&quot; width=&quot;144&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation8.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;border-collapse: separate; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-style: normal; font-variant: normal; font-weight: normal; letter-spacing: normal; line-height: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;font-size: 12px; text-align: justify;&quot;&gt;The Norton equivalent circuit is a current source with current INo in parallel with a resistance RNo. To find the equivalent,&lt;br /&gt;\r\n1. Find the Norton current INo. Calculate the output current, IAB, when a short circuit is the load (meaning 0 resistances between A and B). This is INo.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. Find the Norton resistance RNo. When there are no dependent sources (i.e., all current and voltage sources are independent), there are two methods of determining the Norton impedance RNo.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; Calculate the output voltage, VAB, when in open circuit condition (i.e., no load resistor &amp;mdash; meaning infinite load resistance). RNo equals this VAB divided by INo &lt;br /&gt;\r\nor&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; Replace independent voltage sources with short circuits and independent current sources with open circuits. The total resistance across the output port is the Norton impedance RNo.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nHowever, when there are dependent sources, the more general method must be used. This method is not shown below in the diagrams.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; Connect a constant current source at the output terminals of the circuit with a value of 1 Ampere and calculate the voltage at its terminals. The quotient of this voltage divided by the 1 A current is the Norton impedance RNo. This method must be used if the circuit contains dependent sources, but it can be used in all cases even when there are no dependent sources.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Thevenin&amp;rsquo;s Theorem&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn electrical circuit theory, Thevenin&amp;rsquo;s theorem for linear electrical networks states that any combination of voltage sources, current sources and resistors with two terminals is electrically equivalent to a single voltage source V and a single series resistor R. For single frequency AC systems the theorem can also be applied to general impedances, not just resistors.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nTo calculate the equivalent circuit, one needs a resistance and some voltage - two unknowns. And so, one needs two equations. These two equations are usually obtained by using the following steps, but any conditions one places on the terminals of the circuit should also work:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n1. Calculate the output voltage, VAB, when in open circuit condition (no load resistor - meaning infinite resistance). This is VTh.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. Calculate the output current, IAB, when the output terminals are short circuited (load resistance is 0). RTh equals VTh divided by this IAB.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; The equivalent circuit is a voltage source with voltage VTh in series with a resistance RTh.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nStep 2 could also be thought of like this:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2a. Now replace voltage sources with short circuits and current sources with open circuits.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2b. Replace the load circuit with an imaginary ohm meter and measure the total resistance, R, &amp;quot;looking back&amp;quot; into the circuit. This is RTh.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe Th&amp;eacute;venin-equivalent voltage is the voltage at the output terminals of the original circuit. When calculating a Th&amp;eacute;venin-equivalent voltage, the voltage divider principle is often useful, by declaring one terminal to be Vout and the other terminal to be at the ground point.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;136&quot; width=&quot;152&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation9.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;138&quot; width=&quot;158&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation10.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;138&quot; width=&quot;149&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation11.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The Thevenin-equivalent resistance is the resistance measured across points A and B &amp;quot;looking back&amp;quot; into the circuit. It is important to first replace all voltage- and current-sources with their internal resistances. For an ideal voltage source, this means replace the voltage source with a short circuit. For an ideal current source, this means replace the current source with an open circuit. Resistance can then be calculated across the terminals using the formulae for series and parallel circuits.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  37      (197,'&lt;p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; font-family: Georgia,&#039;Times New Roman&#039;,Times,serif; font-size: 18px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&quot; class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;What is collision?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;The abrupt change to the path of a moving body (or bodies) due to its interaction with other body (or bodies) is called collision. The magnitude and direction of the velocity of the colliding bodies may change in a collision. The force involved in collision may be large, but it acts only for a very short time. We come across many examples of collision daily. The coins of a carom game colliding with one another or collision between two auto mobiles in a road accident etc are examples of collision. Conservation laws applied here are&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;1. Law of conservation of linear momentum: Total linear momentum of a system of particle is conserved if no external force acts on the system. &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            i.e., total linear momentum before collision is equal to total linear momentum after collision, if no external force acts on the system.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            2. Law of conservation of energy: Energy can neither be created nor be destroyer. But can be converted from one form of energy to other.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;36%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot; align=&quot;left&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;img style=&quot;width: 270px; height: 202px;&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/ElasticCollisions.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Types of collision:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n1. Elastic collision: Those collisions in which both momentum and kinetic energy of the system are conserved are called elastic collisions. The collision between subatomic particles is generally elastic. The collision between two steel or glass balls is nearly elastic. In elastic collisions, the forces involved during interaction are of conservative in nature.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. Inelastic collision: Those collisions in which momentum of the system is conserved but not kinetic energy are called inelastic collisions. Most of the collision in everyday life is inelastic.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nCentre of mass of a system of particles: Every physical system has associated with a certain point whose motion characterizes that of the system as a whole. When the system moves under an external force then this point moves in the same way as a single particle would move under the same external force. This point is called centre of mass of the system. The motion of the system can be described in terms of the motion of its centre of mass.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Formulas used:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nIn an elastic collision both kinetic energy and momentum are conserved. In the following equations; 1 and 2 designate the two objects colliding, unprimed variables indicates those before the collision and primed variables indicated after the collisions, p is momentum, KE is kinetic energy, M is mass, and V is velocity. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nConservation of momentum:&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;p1 + p2 = p`1 + p`2&lt;br /&gt;\r\nor&lt;br /&gt;\r\nM1V1 + M2V2 = M1V`1 + M2V`2&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Conservation of kinetic energy:&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;KE1 + KE2 = KE`1 + KE`2&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;or&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;1/2M1(V1)&amp;sup2; + 1/2M2(V2)&amp;sup2; = 1/2M1(V`1)&amp;sup2; + 1/2M2(V`2)&amp;sup2;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Solving these two sets of equations for the velocities after the collision&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-converted-space&quot;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;261&quot; height=&quot;49&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0000.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;and&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;259&quot; height=&quot;49&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0001.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;If M1 = M2 them V1` = V2 and V2` = V1 .&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;If the second object had a velocity V2 = 0 before the collision the equations become&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;158&quot; height=&quot;54&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0002.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;and&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;150&quot; height=&quot;54&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0003.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;If the objects stick together after the collision the collision is a perfectly inelastic collision. In such a collision the velocities of the two objects after the collision are the same. Only momentum is conserved in the inelastic collision. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nConservation of momentum&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;p1 + p2 = p`1 + p`2&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; font-family: Georgia,&#039;Times New Roman&#039;,Times,serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&quot; class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;or&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;M1V1 + M2V2 = M1V`1 + M2V`2&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Since V2 = 0 and V`1 = V`2 the above solved for the velocities after the collision becomes&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;227&quot; height=&quot;54&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image002.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Another approach is to combine elastic and inelastic collisions equations into one equation using the concept of the coefficient of restitution. The coefficient of restitution is defined by the relation&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;96&quot; height=&quot;45&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0004.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: left;&quot;&gt;Where the coefficient of restitution for a perfectly elastic collision is e = 1 and for a perfectly inelastic collision is e = 0. The equation for the velocities after the collision becomes&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;166&quot; height=&quot;54&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001_0005.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; font-family: Georgia,&#039;Times New Roman&#039;,Times,serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&quot; class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  38      (198,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;font class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium; &quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Performing the simulation&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;br type=&quot;_moz&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong&gt;The procedure for the experiment is as follows.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt; &lt;br type=&quot;_moz&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;Choose the type of collision (Elastic or inelastic).The coefficient of restitution slider is fixed to 1 for Elastic collision. The mass and velocity of both the object can be adjusted. The simulation will play on play button click. The graphs like Kinetic energy verses time, Velocity verses time, Momentum verses time for the object depending upon the object movement.. The velocity, momentum and kinetic energy after collision can be find out and can crosscheck with the simulation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: large; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Help&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br type=&quot;_moz&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Variable Region&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;1. Choose Type Combo box helps you to choose the type of collision that the simulation have to perform.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;2. Coefficient of Restitution Slider The slider is fixes to 1 for elastic collision and can change for inelastic collision.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;3. The mass and velocity slider helps to change the mass and velocity values for object A and object B.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;font class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt; &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Measurement Region&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;1. The start button will help play the simulation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  39      (199,'&lt;p&gt;1.&lt;strong&gt; Which of the following statements are true in the case of inelastic collision?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. Only linear momentum is conserved&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Only KE is conserved&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Both linear momentum and KE are conserved&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Coefficient of restitution for a perfectly elastic collision is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. equal to zero&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. equal to one&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. between zero and one&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. greater than one&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. What is the unit of impulse?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. N. s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Kg m/s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. None of the above&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Both&amp;nbsp; &amp;lsquo;a&amp;rsquo; and &amp;lsquo;b&amp;rsquo;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. When two bodies stick together after collision, the collision is said to be&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. Perfectly elastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Perfectly inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Partially inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. The collision between the gas molecules of an ideal gas in a cylinder is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. Perfectly elastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Perfectly inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Partially inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;/p&gt;'),
  40      (201,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;Two balls of mass 5 kg each moving in opposite directions with equal speed say 10 m/s collide head on with each other. Enhanced College Physics.   42      (203,'&lt;p&gt;elastic and inelastic feedback&lt;/p&gt;'),
  43      (204,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What is projectile motion?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;Projectile Motion&quot; width=&quot;283&quot; height=&quot;180&quot; border=&quot;10&quot; align=&quot;right&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; border-top-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); border-right-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); border-bottom-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); border-left-color: rgb(255, 255, 255); &quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/projectile.gif&quot; /&gt;Projectile is defined as any body thrown with some initial velocity and then allowed to move under the action of gravity alone without being propelled by any engine or fuel. The path followed by a projectile is called its trajectory. A projectile moves at a constant speed in the horizontal direction while experiencing a constant acceleration of 9.8 m/s2 downwards in the vertical direction. To be consistent, we define up or upwards to be the positive direction. Therefore the acceleration of gravity is properly -9.8 m/s&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;Horizontal motion of projectile&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;The speed in the horizontal direction is&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vx&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;and this speed doesn&#039;t change. The equation which predicts the position at any time in the horizontal direction is simply&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;x = vx t [equ.1]&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Georgia, &#039;Times New Roman&#039;, Times, serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Georgia, &#039;Times New Roman&#039;, Times, serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;Vertical motion of projectile&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;Because gravity is pulling, the vertical velocity changes constantly. To predict the vertical velocity at any time&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vy&lt;/strong&gt;, we need the following equation:&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vy = voy + a t [equ.2]&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;The&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;voy&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;is simply the original velocity in the vertical or y-direction.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;To calculate the position in the y-direction, the full distance formula must be used.&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;yo&lt;/strong&gt;, which represents the original position in the y-direction.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;yf = yo + voy t + 1/2 a t2&amp;nbsp;[equ.3]&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;Acceleration for projectiles near the Earth&#039;s surface is&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;-9.8 m/s&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;. We don&#039;t re-write the equation with a negative sign; rather, we use the negative acceleration value when solving problems.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;When a projectile is launched horizontally - a ball rolls off a table, a car runs off the edge of a cliff, etc. - the original y-velocity is zero. Your choice of which position to consider y = 0 does not change the final calculation. For example, if the projectile drops 10 meters, you could set the yo = 0 and yf = -10 m. Or you could set yo = 10 m and yf = 0. Either works out the same.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table width=&quot;959&quot; border=&quot;0&quot; class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;Velocity&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;738&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;To determine the total velocity of a projectile, we combine the horizontal velocity&amp;nbsp;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n            (&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vx&lt;/strong&gt;) and the vertical velocity (&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vy&lt;/strong&gt;) using the Pythagorean Theorem:&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;v = (vx2 + vy2)1/2 [equ.4]&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;211&quot; align=&quot;left&quot; valign=&quot;bottom&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&lt;img width=&quot;130&quot; height=&quot;71&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001.gif&quot; /&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Georgia, &#039;Times New Roman&#039;, Times, serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;At maximum height&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;At the top of its path, the projectile no longer is going up and hasn&#039;t started down, yet. Its vertical velocity is zero (&lt;strong style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;vy = 0&lt;/strong&gt;). The only velocity it has is just its horizontal velocity, vx. Remember, the horizontal speed stays constant throughout the projectile path.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;A common misconception occurs at the top of a projectile&#039;s arc. When asked what the acceleration of the projectile is at this point, many people answer &amp;quot;zero&amp;quot;. If it were zero, the projectile would simply keep going in a straight line. However, gravity is still acting, pulling it down, and accelerating it towards the earth. Thus the acceleration at the top is still -9.8 m/s2, just as it&#039;s been all along.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold; &quot;&gt;Range &amp;nbsp;of projectile motion&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;For a projectile that is launched at an angle and returns to the same height, we can determine the range or distance it goes horizontally using a fairly simple equation. However, we will focus on the results of studying that equation rather than solving it here.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;ul style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;ul style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;\r\n        &lt;li class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;When the projectile is launched at a steep angle, it spends more time in the air than it does when launched at a shallow angle.&lt;/li&gt;\r\n        &lt;li class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;When the projectile is launched at a shallow angle, it goes faster in the horizontal direction than if it is launched at a steep angle.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;/ul&gt;\r\n    &lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n    The ideal combination of time in the air and horizontal speed occurs at 45&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;. Thus the maximum range or distance occurs when the projectile is launched at this angle. This applies to long jumpers and soccer balls for two good examples. However, if the projectile starts at a point higher than where it lands, the ideal distance doesn&#039;t occur at a 45&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;angle. Ask your instructor for an explanation. If you calculate the range for a projectile launched at 30&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;, you will find it&#039;s the same as if the same projectile is launched at 60&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;. The same goes for 40&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;and 50&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;. The graph of range vs. angle is symetrical around the 45&lt;sup style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot;&gt;o&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;maximum.&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n    &lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px;   44      (205,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;The simulation helps the user to understand the projectile motion concept.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;Select a type of environment that the simulation has to perform. Gravity changes according to the environment. Fix the velocity, angle of projection and height of the cannon. Range shows the maximum distance the projectile moved.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  45      (208,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Assignment Questions&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; color: rgb(69, 69, 69); font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;1. A brick is thrown upward from the top of a building at an angle of 250 to the horizontal and with an initial speed of 15 m/s. If the brick is flight for 3 s, how tall is the building?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; color: rgb(69, 69, 69); font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;2. A stone is projected with a velocity of 5 m/s making an angle 500 with the vertical.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n(a) Is there any other angle of projection in the X-Y plane having the same range?&amp;nbsp;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n(c) Draw the trajectory of the projectile.&amp;nbsp;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;4. A boy wants to throw a ball through the window of his house to his friend across the street 80 m wide. The window of the boy&amp;rsquo;s house is 10 m below the window of his friend&amp;rsquo;s house. How should he throw the ball?&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; &quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 0px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 0px; color: rgb(69, 69, 69); font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; padding-left: 50px; font-family: Verdana, Geneva, sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;5. Prove that the gun will shoot three times as high when its angle of elevation is 600 as when it is 300, but covers the same horizontal range.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  46      (209,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: larger; &quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;fck_paste_padding&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot; style=&quot;color: rgb(69, 69, 69); &quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; width=&quot;100%&quot; border=&quot;0&quot; class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;margin-top: 0px; margin-right: 0px; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 0px; padding-top: 0px; padding-right: 50px; padding-bottom: 0px; &quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=15zliAL4llE&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;#65279;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  47      (211,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;fck_paste_padding&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: rgb(69, 69, 69);&quot; class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; color: rgb(69, 69, 69);&quot; class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;96%&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;79%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;What is torsional  oscillation?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A body which is suspended by a thread or wire twist the suspension first in one direction and then in reverse direction, but the centre of gravity of the body remains at one place at all the time. Such an oscillation is called torsional oscillation.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            Apparatus- The torsion pendulum consist of a massive disc /cylinder/dumbbell suspended by a thin uniform wire which is firmly fixed to a rigid support. The mass is rotated through a small angle about the wire as the axis and released. The disc makes torsional oscillations. The time taken for one oscillation is called time period of the pendulum (T). The maximum displacement of the pendulum from the mean position is called its amplitude (a).&amp;nbsp; When we place the pendulum in a liquid, the liquid will resist the motion of the pendulum due to its viscosity. Thus the amplitude of oscillation decreases exponentially. This is called damping and the oscillation is called damped harmonic oscillation. Consequently the time period increases. You just do the experiment and experience the deference in time period both in air and in liquid.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A torsion wire is essentially inextensible, but is free to twist about its axis. Of course, as the wire twists it also causes the disk attached to it to rotate in the horizontal plane. Let &amp;theta; be the angle of rotation of the disk. Any twisting of the wire is inevitably associated with mechanical deformation. The wire resists such deformation by developing a restoring torque, which acts to restore the wire to its untwisted state. For relatively small angles of twist, the magnitude of this torque is directly proportional to the twist angle. Hence, we can write.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p align=&quot;center&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;333&quot; width=&quot;250&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image002.gif&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;a style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; text-decoration: none; color: rgb(63, 92, 16);&quot; toptions=&quot;width = 660, height = 440, type = flash, title = Torsion Pendulum&quot; href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/v/EOJbFabRBl0&amp;amp;hl=en&amp;amp;fs=1&amp;amp;rel=0&amp;amp;hd=1&amp;amp;autoplay=1&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p align=&quot;left&quot; style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;object height=&quot;157&quot; width=&quot;261&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;param value=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/v/EOJbFabRBl0?fs=1&amp;amp;hl=en_US&quot; name=&quot;movie&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;param value=&quot;true&quot; name=&quot;allowFullScreen&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;param value=&quot;always&quot; name=&quot;allowscriptaccess&quot; /&gt;&lt;embed height=&quot;300&quot; width=&quot;350&quot; allowfullscreen=&quot;true&quot;
