alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;blockquote style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Where, T is the time period of oscillation and K is couple per unit twist of the material of the wire. I is the moment of inertia of the suspended system, But K= (&amp;pi;nr&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;4&lt;/sup&gt;)/2L, Where,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;blockquote style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;n - Rigidity Modulus of the material of the suspended wire.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nr- Radius of the wire&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;em style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nl &amp;ndash; Length of the wire.&lt;/em&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nMoment of inertia of the Cylinder =&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;(M/12)(R&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;+l&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;)&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nMoment of inertia of the Disc =&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;M (R&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;/2)&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nMoment of inertia of the Dumbbell =&amp;nbsp;&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;M ( ( R&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;/2 ) + 2l&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;)&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nWhen the pendulum is placed in medium, damping forces will come to play. Consequently&amp;nbsp; amplitude and time period of oscillation changes.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nAmplitude of Damping=Ae&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;-&amp;beta;t&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;nbsp;, where A is the amplitude,&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&amp;beta; = &amp;eta;t/2I, where&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&amp;eta; = Coefficient of viscosity of the medium&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nI =Moment of inertia&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nThe angular frequency of the damped oscillator is given by&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&amp;omega;&amp;rsquo;=2&amp;pi;&amp;nu;&amp;rsquo;=[(k/I)-&amp;beta;&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;]&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;1/2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n2&amp;pi;/T=[(k/I)-&amp;beta;&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;]&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;1/2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\nT=2&amp;pi;/ [(k/I)-&amp;beta;&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;2&lt;/sup&gt;]&lt;sup style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;1/2&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/blockquote&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Georgia,&#039;Times New Roman&#039;,Times,serif; font-size: 14px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-weight: bold;&quot; class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;u style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;The simulation objective&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;span style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;The Torsion pendulum simulation will help to analyze various aspect of the torsion oscillation of a string in different medium.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n1.\tDemonstration of Tensional oscillations of different objects such as Disc, Cylinder, Dumbbell.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n2.\tVariation of Tensional oscillations of different objects such as Disc, Cylinder, Dumbbell with change of material of the string.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n3.\tStudy of variation of amplitude of pendulum with time.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n4.\tStudy of variation of damping in different medium such as air, water and Olive oil.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n5.\tCalculates the time period of oscillation.&lt;br style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;fck_paste_padding&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;color: rgb(69, 69, 69);&quot; class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;&lt;blockquote style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; display: inline ! important;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; display: inline ! important;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;6.\tCalculates the Moment of Inertia of the object.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; color: rgb(69, 69, 69);&quot; class=&quot;Apple-style-span&quot;&gt;&lt;blockquote style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px; display: inline ! important;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;margin: 0px; padding: 0px 50px; font-family: Verdana,Geneva,sans-serif; font-size: 12px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); text-align: justify; list-style-position: inside; list-style-type: circle; display: inline ! important;&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/blockquote&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;#65279;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  48      (212,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Performing Torsion Pendulum simulation&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;The simulation virtualizes the torsion pendulum experiment . The user can view the effect of torsional oscillation in different experimental environment. Select any one type of string to suspend the object. Different strings have different rigidity modulus. Choose an environment for the experiment by choose medium combo box. Move the amplitude slider from the initial position to start oscillation. Adjust the moment of inertia by changing the mass and length of the object. The time period of oscillation can be find out using the stop watch.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;Help&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Variable Region&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; span=&quot;&quot;&gt;1. Choose String Combo box helps you to choose the type of string to suspend the material. As the String type changes the string constant also change.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;2. Choose Medium Combo box helps you to select the medium that the suspended material to be kept. As the medium change the damping changes.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;3.  Amplitude Slider  helps you to change the angle of rotation of the material.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;4. Choose Object Combo box helps you to select the object that you want to suspend for the experiment, According to your choice of material the slider will change.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;a.\t Cylinder -\tThere are two sliders for this object for changing the mass and  the length of the cylinder.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;b.\t Disc   - There are two sliders for this object for changing the mass and  the Radius of the Disc.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;c.\t Dumbbell -  There is only one slider for changing the mass at the end.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Measurement Region &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;1.  The moment of inertia value is the value calculated according to the suspended material property.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;2. The Show stop watch check box helps to view the stopwatch. On clicking the start button of the stop watch the time period of one oscillation can be find out.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;3. The show graph check box will change the visibility of Torsional oscillation graph of the material.&lt;/p&gt;'),
  49      (215,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. Its time period in air is &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. 2.33 s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 5.3 s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 4.3 s&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. If the wire is replaced by nylon the time period&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Decreases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Increases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Remains the same&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. If the pendulum is in water the time period&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Decreases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Increases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Remains the same&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. If the amplitude of the pendulum is changed the time period &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Decreases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Increases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Remains the same&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. If the cylinder is replaced by a disc of same mass or radius the time period&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Decreases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Increases&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Remains the same&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  50      (216,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div id=&quot;ISBN:9780471320579&quot; style=&quot;display: block;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Resnick, Robert et.al. New York: John Wiley, 1996.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;             &lt;!--{12853909610751}--&gt;             &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;3&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div id=&quot;ISBN:9780495113744&quot; style=&quot;display: block;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Serway, Raymond et.al. Enhanced College Physics. Pacific Grove: Brooks Cole, 2006.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;             &lt;!--{12853909610752}--&gt;             &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;   &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Webiliography&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/TorsionalPendulum.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; class=&quot;externalLink&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://scienceworld.wolfram.com/physics/TorsionalPendulum.html&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_moments_of_inertia&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; class=&quot;externalLink&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_moments_of_inertia&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.upscale.utoronto.ca/IYearLab/Intros/TorsionPend/TorsionPend.html&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot; class=&quot;externalLink&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.upscale.utoronto.ca/IYearLab/Intros/TorsionPend/TorsionPend.html&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Video References&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLrgeQzFkGA&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CLrgeQzFkGA&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUlKbitQYlU&quot; target=&quot;_blank&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mUlKbitQYlU &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  51      (381,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. The law which relates current, voltage and resistance in a circuit is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Ohm&amp;rsquo;s law&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Faraday&amp;rsquo;s law&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Joule&amp;rsquo;s law&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Lenz&amp;rsquo;s law&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. The resistance of a conductor depends on&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Length of the conductor&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Area of cross section of the conductor&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Temperature&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. All the above&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;3. The direction of electric current outside a cell is&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. From positive terminal to negative terminal&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. From higher potential to a lower potential&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Electron deficient terminal to electron rich terminal&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. All the above&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;4.&amp;nbsp;Which of the following material is best for making connecting wires&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Tungsten&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Nichrome&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Copper&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Constantan&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;5. In which of the following substances the resistance decreases with increase in temperature&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Carbon&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Constantan&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Copper&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Silver&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  52      (220,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. Which of the following statements are true in the case of inelastic collision? &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Only linear momentum is conserved&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Only KE is conserved&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Both linear momentum and KE are conserved. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Coefficient of restitution for a perfectly elastic collision is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. equal to zero&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. equal to one&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. between zero and one&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. greater than one&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. What is the unit of impulse?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. N. s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Kg m/s&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. None of the above&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Both&amp;nbsp; &amp;lsquo;a&amp;rsquo; and &amp;lsquo;b&amp;rsquo;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. When two bodies stick together after collision, the collision is said to be;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Perfectly elastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Perfectly inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Partially inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. The collision between the gas molecules of an ideal gas in a cylinder is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Perfectly elastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Perfectly inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Partially inelastic&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  53      (218,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;What is collision?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The abrupt change to the path of a moving body (or bodies) due to its interaction with other body (or bodies) is called collision. The magnitude and direction of the velocity of the colliding bodies may change in a collision. The force involved in collision may be large, but it acts only for a very short time. We come across many examples of collision daily. The coins of a carom game colliding with one another or collision between two auto mobiles in a road accident etc are examples of collision. Conservation laws applied here are&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp; 1.Law of conservation of linear momentum:&amp;nbsp; Total linear momentum of a system of particle is conserved if no external force acts on the system. i.e., total&amp;nbsp; linear momentum&amp;nbsp; before collision is equal to total linear momentum after collision, if no external force acts on the system.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp; 2.Law of conservation of energy: Energy can neither be created nor be destroyer. But can be converted from one form of energy to other.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; &lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Types of collision:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1. Elastic collision: Those collisions in which both momentum and kinetic energy of the system are conserved are called elastic collisions. The collision between subatomic particles is generally elastic. The collision between two steel or glass balls is nearly elastic. In elastic collisions, the forces involved during interaction are of conservative in nature.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;2. Inelastic collision:&amp;nbsp; Those collisions in which momentum of the system is conserved but not kinetic energy are called inelastic collisions. Most of the collision in everyday life is inelastic.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Centre of mass of a system of particles: Every physical system has associated with a certain point whose motion characterizes that of the system as a whole. When the system moves under an external force then this point moves in the same way as a single particle would move under the same external force. This point is called centre of mass of the system. The motion of the system can be described in terms of the motion of its centre of mass.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;       &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;Formulas used:&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Elastic and Inelastic Collision in Two Dimensions&lt;br /&gt;\r\nHere for the determination of the &#039;impact angle&#039;, the hard sphere model which obviously would only be an approximation for charged particles (strictly speaking the Rutherford scattering formula would have to be used for this). Apart from this, the solution below is a completely general and exact description of a 2D collision event (and in any case it provides exact conservation of momentum and energy). &lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe relationship between the velocities of masses m1 and m2 before the collision (unprimed) and after the collision (primed) is given by the conservation equations for momentum and energy: &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(1) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; m1.vx,1  = m1.vx,1&#039; + m2.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(2) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; m1.vy,1  = m1.vy,1&#039; + m2.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;.tan(&amp;theta;) &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; (3) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; m1/2.(vx,12+vy,12)  = m1/2.(vx,1&#039;2+vy,1&#039;2)  + m2/2.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;2.(1+tan2(&amp;theta;))  &amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; For the sake of simplicity it has been assumed here that mass 2 is initially resting i.e. vx,2=0, vy,2=0 and vx,2&#039;=&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039; (this does not affect the general validity of the final result as the assumption will be dropped again later by referring the velocities to mass 2 explicitly).&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The angle &amp;theta; in Eq.(2) (and (3)) is the angle of the final velocity vector of ball 2 with the x-axis. This will be determined separately later from the geometry of the collision (alternatively, one can also treat &amp;theta; as a free parameter).&lt;br /&gt;\r\nSolving now Eq.(1) for vx,1&#039;  and Eq.(2) for vy,1&#039; yields &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(4) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,1&#039;  = vx,1 - m2/m1.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(5) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,1&#039;  = vy,1 - m2/m1.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;.tan(&amp;theta;)  &amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Inserting (4) and (5) into Eq.(3) results in a quadratic equation for &amp;Delta;vx,2&#039; which (after some lengthy but straightforward algebraic manipulations) yields the solution: &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; (6) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;  = 2[ vx,1 + tan(&amp;theta;).vy,1 ] / [(1+tan2(&amp;theta;)).(1+m2  /m1 )] &amp;nbsp; . &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; Referring now the initial velocities explicitly to ball 2 and noting that the angle &amp;theta; is the sum of the relative velocity angle between ball 1 and 2 &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(7) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;gamma;v  = arctan [ (vy,1-vy,2)/(vx,1-vx,2)  ] &lt;br /&gt;\r\nand the impact angle &amp;alpha; (see  below); one can finally write &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(8) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;  = 2[ vx,1 - vx,2 + a.(vy,1 - vy,2  ) ] / [(1+a2).(1+m2 /m1 )] &amp;nbsp; , &lt;br /&gt;\r\nwhere&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;(9) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; a =  tan(&amp;theta;) = tan(&amp;gamma;v+&amp;alpha;) &amp;nbsp; . &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; The &#039;impact angle&#039; &amp;alpha; can vary between -90o and +90o (or -&amp;pi;/2 and &amp;pi;/2 when using radians) (0o corresponds to a head-on- and the extreme values to a grazing collision). (in most treatments of collision problems, the center-of -mass scattering angle &amp;Theta; is used, which relates to &amp;alpha; through &amp;alpha;=(&amp;pi;-&amp;Theta;)/2; however, as &amp;alpha; is independent of the reference frame, it is a much better choice here).&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The actual value of &amp;alpha; depends on the exact coordinates of the particles, so if the latter are not known, one has to treat &amp;alpha; as a free parameter and generate it for instance through a random number generator. (otherwise see below for the determination of &amp;alpha;).&lt;br /&gt;\r\nFrom Eqs.(2),(4),(5),(8),and  (9) the velocity components after the collision are therefore: &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(10) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,2&#039;  = vx,2 + &amp;Delta;vx,2&#039; &amp;nbsp; ,&lt;br /&gt;\r\n(11) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,2&#039; = vy,2 + a .&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;  &amp;nbsp; ,&lt;br /&gt;\r\n(12) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,1&#039; = vx,1 - m2/m1.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;  &amp;nbsp; ,&lt;br /&gt;\r\n(13) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,1&#039; = vy,1 - a. m2/m1.&amp;Delta;vx,2&#039;  &amp;nbsp; . &lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe &#039;impact angle&#039; &amp;alpha; in  Eq.(9) can be determined from the collision geometry as shown in the  illustration below:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;320&quot; width=&quot;321&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/theory_clip_image001(1).gif&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Geometry of 2D collision&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;If the coordinates of the  balls (with radius r1 and r2) are x1,y1  and x2,y2, &amp;alpha; is given by &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(14) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;alpha; =  arcsin [ d.sin(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v) / (r1+r2)  ] , &lt;br /&gt;\r\nwhere &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(15) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; d =  &amp;radic; [ (x2-x1)2 +(y2-y1)2  ] , &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(16) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;gamma;x,y= arctan [ (y2-y1)/((x2-x1)  ] ,&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThis will give a value for &amp;alpha; as long as the absolute value of d1,2.sin(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v) &amp;le;(r1+r2) (otherwise the arcsin- function above is not defined, in which case the balls would not collide anyway). Note that one also has to exclude the case where &amp;gamma;x,y and &amp;gamma;v differ by more then &amp;pi;/2 and less than 1.5*&amp;pi; as then the balls would move away from each other. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nIf one is tracking the balls for further collisions, it is also necessary to update the coordinates in addition to the velocities. This is achieved as follows: using the law of cosines for the collision triangle and solving the corresponding quadratic equation for the distance which ball 1 travels to the collision point, one obtains the time that elapses from the original coordinates to the collision as&lt;br /&gt;\r\n(17) &amp;nbsp; t = { d.cos(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v)  &amp;plusmn; &amp;radic; [(r1+r2)2- (d.sin(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v))  2] } / &amp;radic; [ (vx,1-vx,2)2 +(vy,1-vy,2)2  ] . &lt;br /&gt;\r\nBefore the first square root,  the minus sign holds if cos(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v)&amp;gt;0 and the plus  sign otherwise.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nNote again that a valid solution requires |d.sin(&amp;gamma;x,y-&amp;gamma;v)|  &amp;le; (r1+r2) (otherwise the balls would not collide).&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe new coordinates (the position of the center of the balls at the moment of  collision) are therefore&lt;br /&gt;\r\n(18) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; x1&#039;  = x1 + vx,1.t &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(19) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; y1&#039; = y1 + vy,1.t &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(20) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; x2&#039; = x2 + vx,2.t &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(21) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; y2&#039; = y2 + vy,2.t &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;Generalization to Inelastic  Collisions&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe generalization of the above formulae to inelastic collisions is ultimately simple: &amp;nbsp; we just have to refer the velocity components (Eq.(10)-(13)) to the center of mass reference frame, apply the restitution coefficient to these, and add again the center of mass velocity to return to the lab frame, i.e. with &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(22) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,cm  = ( m1.vx,1 + m2.vx,2  )/( m1+ m2) &amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(23) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,cm = ( m1.vy,1  + m2.vy,2 )/( m1+ m2)  &amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\nwe have &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(24) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,1&#039;&#039;  = (vx,1&#039;-vx,cm).R + vx,cm&amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(25) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,1&#039;&#039; = (vy,1&#039;-vy,cm).R  + vy,cm&amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(26) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vx,2&#039;&#039; = (vx,2&#039;-vx,cm).R  + vx,cm&amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(27) &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp; vy,2&#039;&#039; = (vy,2&#039;-vy,cm).R  + vy,cm&amp;nbsp; &lt;br /&gt;\r\nwhere R is the restitution coefficient (=1 for a perfectly elastic collision; =0 for a perfectly inelastic collision (balls stick together after the collision)). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  54      (219,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Performing the simulation&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe procedure for the experiment is as follows:&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe collision ball is used to demonstrate the elastic movement of the ball. The velocity and direction of the balls can be set by dragging the balls. The position of the balls can be changed by dragging the inner circle of the ball. The movement can be started by using the start button.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Variable Region&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n1. Coefficient of Restitution Slider is used for inelastic collision it can  move from 0 to 1.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2. The mass slider helps to change the mass values for object  A and object B.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n3. Show center of mass check box help to enable and disable  the center of mass of the objects.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n4. The play and pause button are used to reset and pause the  movement of the ball.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;u&gt;Measurement Region &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;Shows the  velocity and kinetic energy of the Object A and B&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  55      (225,'&lt;table cellspacing=&quot;1&quot; cellpadding=&quot;1&quot; border=&quot;0&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;What is a Ballistic pendulum?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A ballistic pendulum is a device for measuring a bullet&#039;s momentum, from which it is possible to calculate the velocity and kinetic energy. Ballistic pendulums have been largely rendered obsolete by modern chronographs, which allow direct measurement of the projectile velocity.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;What is its use?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;div class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;It is used to measure the velocity and momentum of a projectile or the recoil of a gun. The ballistic pendulum can be used to measure any transfer of momentum. For example, a ballistic pendulum was used by physicist C. V. Boys to measure the elasticity of golf balls, and by physicist Peter Guthrie Tait to measure the effect that spin had on the distance a golf ball traveled. In a perfectly inelastic collision, a bullet is fired into the stationary pendulum, which captures the bullet and absorbs its energy. The stationary pendulum now moves with a new velocity just after the collision. While not all of the energy from the bullet is transformed into kinetic energy for the pendulum (some is used as heat and deformation energy) the momentum of the system is conserved. By measuring the height of the pendulum&#039;s swing, the potential energy of the pendulum when it stops can be measured. In the case of a pendulum total mechanical energy is conserved. So kinetic energy of the pendulum (after firing) is fully converted to potential energy. This allows the pendulum&#039;s initial velocity to be calculated.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;236&quot; align=&quot;right&quot; width=&quot;250&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/balastic.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;Using the conservation of momentum, the velocity of the bullet can be computed.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;If&lt;br /&gt;\r\nm- Mass of bullet&lt;br /&gt;\r\nM- Mass of Pendulum&lt;br /&gt;\r\nh- Maximum height reached by the pendulum&lt;br /&gt;\r\nv-Velocity of the bullet&lt;br /&gt;\r\nV- Velocity of pendulum&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;From the law of conservation of mechanical energy of the pendulum&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;frac12; (m+M)V2= (m+M)gh&lt;br /&gt;\r\nV= &amp;radic;(2gh)&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;According to the law of conservation of momentum,&lt;br /&gt;\r\nmv= (M+m)V&lt;br /&gt;\r\nmv= (M+m) &amp;radic;(2gh)&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;           Velocity of the bullet is given by&lt;br /&gt;\r\nv=(1/m)(M+m) &amp;radic;(2gh)&lt;br /&gt;\r\nv= (1+M/m) &amp;radic;(2gh)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  56      (226,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitle&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: medium;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Performing Ballistic Pendulum simulation&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;A ballistic pendulum is a device for measuring a bullet&#039;s momentum, from which it is possible to calculate the velocity and kinetic energy. Ballistic pendulums have been largely rendered obsolete by modern chronographs, which allow direct measurement of the projectile velocity.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Variable Region&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Velocity: It helps you to fix the velocity of the bullet.&lt;br pendulum.=&quot;&quot; the=&quot;&quot; of=&quot;&quot; mass=&quot;&quot; fix=&quot;&quot; to=&quot;&quot; you=&quot;&quot; helps=&quot;&quot; it=&quot;&quot; mass:=&quot;&quot; block=&quot;&quot; /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMass of bullet: This helps to change the mass of the bullet.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Measurement Region&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Amplitude is the oscillation of the pendulum.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMax height shows the maximum height the pendulum reached.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMax angle is the maximum angle of the pendulum reached when applying the inputted values.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nThe show sine graph button will change the visibility of ballistic pendulum oscillation graph.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  57      (230,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot; class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div id=&quot;ISBN:1421265737&quot; style=&quot;display: block;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;1421265737&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Quackenbos, George. A Natural Philosophy. City: Adamant Media Corporation, 2005.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;             &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:1421265737&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;             &lt;script type=&quot;text/javascript&quot; src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books/api.js?key=notsupplied&amp;amp;v=0&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;             &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;2.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div id=&quot;ISBN:812650868X&quot; style=&quot;display: block;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;812650868X&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Touger, Jerold. Introductory Physics, Building Understanding. New York: Wiley, 2006.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;             &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:812650868X&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;             &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;3&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div id=&quot;ISBN:9788126514519&quot; style=&quot;display: block;&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;9788126514519&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Cutnell, Johnson. Physics, 5Th Ed, Wiley-India, 2007&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;             &lt;script    &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br     &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot;         &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span Rotational Inertia&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; Verdana;&quot;&gt;Amrita Viswa Vidyapeetham&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;IIT Delhi&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- U G All Branches (PHP100)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;IIT Kanpur&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- U G All Branches&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;NIT Tiruchirapally&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- B Tech All Branches&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Andhra University&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- B Sc Physics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Kakatiya University&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- B Sc Physics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Osmania University&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;10%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- B Sc Physics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Under Graduate (UG)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  58      (268,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Components&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;   Resistor:&lt;/strong&gt; A resistor is a two-terminal electronic component that produces a voltage across its terminals that is proportional to the electric current through it in accordance with Ohm&#039;s law.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tLamp:&lt;/strong&gt; A lamp is a replaceable component such as an incandescent light bulb, which is designed to produce light from electricity. These components usually have a base of ceramic, metal, glass or plastic, which makes an electrical connection in the socket of a light fixture.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tWire:&lt;/strong&gt; A wire is a single, usually cylindrical, elongated string of metal. Wires are used to bear mechanical loads and to carry electricity and telecommunications signals. Wire is commonly formed by drawing the metal through a hole in a die or draw plate.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tSwitch:&lt;/strong&gt; In electronics, a switch is an electrical component that can break an electrical circuit, interrupting the current or diverting it from one conductor to another.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tBattery:&lt;/strong&gt; In electronics, a battery or voltaic cell is a combination of many electrochemical Galvanic cells of identical type to store chemical energy and to deliver higher voltage or higher current than with single cells.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tVoltmeter:&lt;/strong&gt; A voltmeter is an instrument used for measuring the electrical potential difference between two points in an electric circuit. Analog voltmeters move a pointer across a scale in proportion to the voltage of the circuit; digital voltmeters give a numerical display of voltage by use of an analog to digital converter.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tAmmeter:&lt;/strong&gt; An ammeter is a measuring instrument used to measure the electric current in a circuit. Electric currents are measured in amperes (A), hence the name.&#039;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&amp;bull;\tNon-contact ammeter:&lt;/strong&gt; A type of ammeter that need not be a part of the circuit.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1.\tBuilding DC Circuits and taking measurements&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Refer the user manual for instructions on assembling a circuit and taking current and voltage readings at any points. This experiment is intended for the user to get used to basic components in DC circuits and their roles.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Verifying Ohm&amp;rsquo;s Law&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The procedure to verify ohm&amp;rsquo;s law is as follows:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tOpen the Virtual Lab DC Circuit Simulation.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tUsing the Instructions given in the user manual construct a circuit equivalent to the one given below. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;180&quot; width=&quot;209&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation12.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull;\tNow set the resistance of R to say 2 ohms.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; Keeping the resistance constant, vary the value of V and in each case measure the current flowing across the Resistor, R.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tRecord the readings and plot a graph with current on y- axis and voltage on the x axis.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tVerify if the graph is liner.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Verifying parallel and series connections&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Procedure to verify series and parallel connections are as follows:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tConstruct a circuit with two resistances R1 and R2 connected in series with a battery and an ammeter.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tClose the circuit and verify if the current flowing through both are the same and record the observation.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tMeasure the voltage drop across each of the resistances and record the observations.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tNow calculate the equivalent resistance R as R1 + R2.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tReplace R1 and R2 with a single resistance equivalent to R.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tNow measure the current and voltage across R and record the readings&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tCompare the readings with the previous readings.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tRepeat the experiment for R1 and R2 connected in parallel.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tVerify both the results are concurrent with the theoretical values.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. Studying the nature of bulbs connected in series and parallel&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Procedure to verify series and parallel connections are as follows:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tConstruct a circuit with two Bulbs B1 and B2 connected in series with a battery V1.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tChoose B1 and B2 such that power rating of B1 is less than that of B2 (PB1&amp;lt;PB2)&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tNow close the circuit and see the glow produced by both the bulbs. Record the observations.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tAlso note down the voltage drop across each of the bulbs.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tRepeat the experiment with B1 and B2 connected in parallel. Record the observations.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tCompare the observations in each case and verify if they are in accordance with the theory.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. Verifying Kirchhoff&amp;rsquo;s voltage and current laws.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Procedure to verify series and parallel connections are as follows:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tConstruct a circuit as shown in the figure using resistors and batteries.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;250&quot; width=&quot;401&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation13.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull;\tUsing the ammeters record the current reading at every junction.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tFor each junction verify if the total incoming current is equal to the total outgoing current.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tUsing the voltmeter record the voltage drop across each resistor.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull;\tNow add up the drops over the different resistances in any mesh and verify if it&amp;rsquo;s the total voltage source in the mesh.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6. Verifying Thevenin&amp;rsquo;s theorem.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Procedure to verify Thevenin&amp;rsquo;s Theorem is as follows:-&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull;\tConstruct the circuit as shown in Figure&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;162&quot; width=&quot;599&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation14.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull;\tMeasure the open circuit voltage between terminals A-B.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;bull; The short circuit current between terminals A-B can be measured by connecting an ammeter across terminals A-B. It is assumed that the internal resistance of the ammeter is low enough that it appears as a short circuit to the circuit between terminals A-B. Measured value of the short circuit current below. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull; Now short circuit DC supplies. An open circuit should exist between terminals A-B. Calculate the Thevenin equivalent resistance, Rt, at terminals A-B.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull; The next step is to measure the load current, iL, and the load voltage, vL, of the circuit in figure. . To perform the first of these tasks, connect the 10 k&amp;Omega; load resistor in series with an ammeter and measure iL. Measure the voltage drop across RL. Record the values of iL and vL.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;186&quot; width=&quot;455&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation15.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull; Now measure the open circuit voltage of the above circuit at terminals A-B. Record this value below and compare with the results of step 3 of the experimental exercise. This measurement verifies the equivalence of the two circuits under open circuit loading conditions. Note that RL is infinitely large and iL is zero in this case. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull; Using an ammeter, measure the short circuit current of this circuit between terminals A-B. Record below and compare with the results of step 4 of this experiment. This measurement verifies the equivalence of the two circuits under short circuit loading conditions. Note that vL = 0 in this case. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull; Next connect the 10 k&amp;Omega; load resistor between the terminals of the circuit in 2nd Figure. Measure iL . Also measure vL . Compare these values with the results of step 6 of this experiment. These measurements verify the equivalence of the two circuits under &amp;ldquo;in-between&amp;rdquo; loading conditions. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;7. Verifying Norton&amp;rsquo;s theorem.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Procedure to verify Norton&amp;rsquo;s Theorem is as follows:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;bull;\tConstruct a circuit as shown in the figure using resistors and batteries.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;258&quot; width=&quot;467&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/equation16.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: left;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1. Now disconnect voltage sources from the circuit and replace them with short circuit. For this state, measure the net resistance across &lt;strong&gt;a &lt;/strong&gt;and &lt;strong&gt;b&lt;/strong&gt;.  This value is the Norton Resistance &lt;strong&gt;(RTH) &lt;/strong&gt;across &lt;strong&gt;a &lt;/strong&gt;and &lt;strong&gt;b&lt;/strong&gt;.         2. Reconnect  power supplies. Then measure short-circuit current across the terminals &lt;strong&gt;a &lt;/strong&gt;and &lt;strong&gt;b&lt;/strong&gt;. This current is the Norton current (&lt;strong&gt;IN&lt;/strong&gt;).          3. Vary the value  of RL and measure the current through RL for each value.       &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  59      (272,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Reference:&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; class=&quot;content&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: block;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780891001218&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Rosen, Stan. D. C. Circuits. Riverton: Aviation Maintenance Publishers, 1980.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780891001218&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;2.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: block;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9780835204101&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Mapp, Edward. Books for Occupational Education Programs. New York: Bowker, 1971.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/div&gt;\r\n            &lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;script src=&quot;http://books.google.com/books?jscmd=viewapi&amp;amp;bibkeys=ISBN:9780835204101&amp;amp;callback=processDynamicLinksResponse&quot; type=&quot;text/javascript&quot;&gt;&lt;/script&gt;\r\n            &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;       &lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;       &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Webliography:&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; \t  &lt;br /&gt;\r\n1.\tModified Nodal Analysis. [ &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.swarthmore.edu/NatSci/echeeve1/Ref/mna/MNA1.html&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.swarthmore.edu/NatSci/echeeve1/Ref/mna/MNA1.html&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; ]&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2.\tMatrix operations. [ &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LU_decomposition&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LU_decomposition&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; ]&lt;br /&gt;\r\n3.\tGraph theory. [ &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_theory &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;]&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
  60      (358,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;An ordinary light source consists of a very large number of randomly oriented atomic emitters which radiates polarized wavetrains for roughly 10&lt;sup&gt;-8&lt;/sup&gt; s. All these wavetrains combine to form a single  resultant polarized wave which persists for not more than 10&lt;sup&gt;-8&lt;/sup&gt; s. Natural light composes of a large number of rapidly varying succession of the different polarization states.&amp;nbsp; It is therefore said to be an unpolarised or randomly polarized light. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;         &lt;!--leave this space as such.. som wired issue--&gt;       \t  &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;We can express this natural light in terms of two arbitrary, incoherent, orthogonal, linearly polarized waves of equal amplitude (figure (a) shows natural light having different polarization states and figure (b) showing splitting 50% horizontal and 50% vertical states).&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot; style=&quot;text-align: center;&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;150&quot; width=&quot;150&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image002.png&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;150&quot; width=&quot;150&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image004.png&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;
