          &lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Video References&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XMfYHag7Liw&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XMfYHag7Liw&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IueC-weQHS8&amp;amp;feature=related&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IueC-weQHS8&amp;amp;feature=related&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kUbsUGjRlTk&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kUbsUGjRlTk&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/a&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Experiment Mapping &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table width=&quot;85%&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;tagExpHead&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Subject&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;33%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Courses&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n            &lt;th width=&quot;34%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;span class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;Level&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/th&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;txtarea&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td colspan=&quot;3&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Physics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- Mechanics&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;5%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;90%&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;- Collision&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot;&gt;\r\n                &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Under Graduate (UG)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                    &lt;tr&gt;\r\n                        &lt;td width=&quot;95%&quot; colspan=&quot;2&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Graduate (G)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n                    &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n                &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n            &lt;/table&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 134      (470,'&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;What is A.C. Sonometer?&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;An A.C sonometer is an apparatus by which the transverse vibrations of \t\t\tstrings can be studied. It consists of two bridges, near the ends, one \t\thorse shoe magnet at the middle and at one end is a pulley. A string, \t\toften a copper wire, is fastened at one end, run over the bridges and \t\tthe pulley, and attached to a weight holder hanging below the pulley. \t\tWeights can be added to the holder to produce tension in the wire, and \t\tthe bridges can be moved to change the length of the vibrating section \t\tof the string. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Theory            &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Every object has a natural frequency of vibration. If kinetic energy is applied to an object at a rate that matches its natural frequency, resonance occurs and the object vibrates. In this experiment a small current, produced by a signal generator, causes the sonometer wire to move up and down due to interaction with the magnetic field of a U-shaped magnet. When the rate of movement due to the current matches the fundamental frequency of the wire, resonance occurs causing noticeable vibration.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nTo determine the frequency of a string first place a copper string. Connect with an A.C power supply. Then adjust the knife edges or the magnet to get the maximum vibration. This will be the frequency of the stretched string. &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; To determine the frequency of a string first place a copper string. Connect with an A.C power supply. Then adjust the knife edges or the magnet to get the maximum vibration. This will be the frequency of the stretched string. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Frequency of vibration of a stretched string       &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;183&quot; width=&quot;309&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image1.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The frequency is calculated using the equation &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;49&quot; width=&quot;85&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image2.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;------Equation(1)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;L = resonating length&lt;br /&gt;\r\nT = tension at the string&lt;br /&gt;\r\nm = mass/unit length of the wire. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Derivation of the equation:-              &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;     Laws of transverse vibrations of stretched strings&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;43&quot; width=&quot;131&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image3.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;43&quot; width=&quot;159&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image4.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;45&quot; width=&quot;75&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image5.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;49&quot; width=&quot;85&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image6.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Law of length&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For a given string under constant tension, the frequency of vibration is inversely proportional to the length of the string.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;48&quot; width=&quot;80&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image7.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Law of tension&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;          For a given string of constant length, the frequency of vibration is directly proportional to the square root of the tension.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;35&quot; width=&quot;104&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image8.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Law of mass&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For a string of constant length and under a constant tension, the frequency of vibration is inversely proportional to the square root of its mass per unit length. If M is the mass and L is the length of the string, then&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;45&quot; width=&quot;207&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image9.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;45&quot; width=&quot;191&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image10.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;25&quot; width=&quot;81&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image11.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;If d is the diameter of the wire, then&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;48&quot; width=&quot;75&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image12.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;51&quot; width=&quot;89&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image13.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Substituting in equation (1), we get&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;73&quot; width=&quot;124&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image14.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;51&quot; width=&quot;89&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image15.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The law of mass may be put into two additional laws, for strings of circular cross-section, as given below.                   &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Law of diameter&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;            For a string of a given material and length and under a constant tension, the frequency is inversely proportional to its diameter.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;42&quot; width=&quot;77&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image16.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Law of density&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For a string of a given length and diameter and under constant tension, the frequency is inversely proportional to the square root of the density of the material of the string.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;img height=&quot;50&quot; width=&quot;93&quot; src=&quot;DATABASEPROJECTROOTFOLDERNAMEuserfiles/image17.jpg&quot; alt=&quot;&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 135      (471,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;The simulation will start play on the power button click. Now the string starts vibrating. Adjust the knife edges or the magnet to get the maximum vibration. At the maximum vibration the paper rider placed in the string will fall down. Repeat the same for different weight, radius, string material and environment. Using Reset button you can reset the simulation.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; \t       &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Icons&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;                Power On - To start the power supply.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nPower Off - To stop the power supply.        &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Variable Region&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt; Slider&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Weight Rings - To add/remove weight rings.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nKnife Edge A - To move knife edge A.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nKnife Edge B - To move knife edge A.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nMagnet position - To move magnet &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Combo box&lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;         Choose Radius - To set different radius.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nChoose String material - To select different types of wires&lt;br /&gt;\r\nChoose environment - To select different environments&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Measurement Region &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Showing string frequency&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;u&gt;Button &lt;/u&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Reset - To resetting the simulation.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h3&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/h3&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 136      (475,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;For more info on one may read books, visit labs or check for other web contents. Here are some choices for reading material. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Books&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table border=&quot;0&quot; width=&quot;100%&quot; style=&quot;margin-left: 70px;&quot; id=&quot;myTable&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;3%&quot; valign=&quot;top&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;1.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td width=&quot;97%&quot;&gt;\r\n            &lt;div style=&quot;display: none;&quot; id=&quot;ISBN:9788122417487&quot;&gt;&lt;a href=&quot;javascript:togglePreview(&#039;9788122417487&#039;);&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Srivastava, Anchal.           &lt;!--\r\n&lt;body onUnload=&quot;checkEmbeddability();&quot; &gt;\r\n&lt;/body&gt;\r\n--&gt;     &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;div class=&quot;postConentPadding&quot;&gt;\r\n&lt;link type=&quot;text/css&quot;  137      (598,'&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;gsdfsdfsdfsdf&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;sd&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;f&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;sd&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;f&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;sdf&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;sd&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;f&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;sdff&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;s&lt;/p&gt;'),
 138      (206,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. &amp;nbsp;Which among the following is not a vector?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a.&amp;nbsp;Electric current&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Force&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Momentum&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Acceleration&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. The resultant of two vectors is minimum when the angle between them is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. 0&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 5&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 90&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. 180&amp;ordm;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. The maximum number of rectangular components into which a vector can be resolved in its own plane is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. 1&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 2&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 3&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. 4&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. The projectile has maximum value of time of flight, when it is projected at an angle of projection&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. 0&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 5&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 90&amp;ordm;&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. 180&amp;ordm;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. The maximum height reached by a particle is independent of&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;a. Angle of projection&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Initial velocity&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Acceleration of the projectile&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Mass of the projectile&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 139      (213,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. The time taken by a pendulum to complete one oscillation is called its&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Time period&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Amplitude&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Frequency&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Velocity&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. The maximum displacement of the torsion pendulum from its mean position is called&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Time period&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Amplitude&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Frequency&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Velocity&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Which of the following statement is correct&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Up thrust is equal to the weight of the liquid displaced by the body&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Up thrust = Volume of the body x density of liquid x acceleration due to gravity&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Up thrust is equal to loss of weight of body in liquid&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. All the above&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. The moment of inertia of a disc of mass M and radius R, about an axis passing through its centre and perpendicular to the plane of the disc is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. MR2&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. (1/2)MR2&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. (1/4)MR2&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. (3/4)MR2&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 140      (222,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;Two balls, one of mass (A) 1 kg &amp;nbsp;and the other of mass (B) 5 kg are moving in opposite directions with equal speed say 5 m/s collide head on with each other. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nWatch the collision in the simulator when  &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(i) the coefficient of restitution is 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, 0.8 and 1. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nWhat is your  conclusion? &lt;br /&gt;\r\n(ii) Predict the motion in perfectly inelastic case (when  coefficient of restitution is zero). &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),

The ferromagnetic solid itself.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. None of these&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 148      (390,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;1. Sequence the domain movement in the external magnetic field.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p align=&quot;center&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; width=&quot;624&quot; height=&quot;153&quot; src=&quot;http://sakshat.amrita.ac.in/VirtualLab/vlab/PHY/EMM/BarkhausenEffect/assignment_clip_image002_0000.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;A) Growth of the domains parallel to the applied field at the expense of other domains and then the reorientation of the domains themselves. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nB) The orientation of the domains and then growth of the domains parallel to the applied field. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nC) The orientation of each domain in the applied field. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nD) None of these. &lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;2.  155      (395,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;1. A hollow metal sphere of radius 5 cm is charged such that the potential on its surface is 10 V. The potential at the centre of the sphere is&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Zero&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. 10 V&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Same as at a point 5 cm away from the surface&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Same as at a point 10 cm away from the surface&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;2. Insulated copper spheres of radii 10 cm and 15 cm and having equal charges are connected by a copper wire and separated.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Both spheres will have the same charge&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Charges on 15 cm sphere will be greater than that on 10 cm sphere.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Charges on 10 cm sphere will be greater than that on 15 cm sphere.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Charges on both sphere become zero.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;3.  161      (404,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;1.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;Find out the factors in which the thermo electric emf produced in a thermocouple depends.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n2.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;One junction of a thermocouple is kept at 00C and the other junction is heated. Discuss the variation of thermo emf with temperature.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n3.&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;The relation between thermo emf and temperature of hot junction is Given &amp;alpha; =41 &amp;micro;V 0C-1 and &amp;beta;=0.041 &amp;micro;V 0C-2 and E=0.0082 V.  170      (313,'&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt; A  100&amp;micro;H inductor passes a current of 10 mA when its terminal voltage is 6.3 V.  Calculate the frequency of ac supply. &lt;br /&gt;\r\nA  4.5 &amp;micro;F capacitor passes a current of 34 mA when connected to a 100 Hz supply.  Calculate the supply voltage.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nA parallel RL circuit consist of a 68 &amp;Omega; resistor and a 10 mH inductor with a 5 V, 1 kHz supply. Calculate the branch currents, supply current and the phase angle of the supply current and the phase angle of the supply current with respect to the supply voltage.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nA Parallel RC circuits consist of a 68 &amp;Omega; resistor and a 0.015 &amp;micro;F capacitor with a 3V, 3.3 kHz supply. Calculate the branch currents, supply current and the phase angle of the supply current and the phase angle of the supply current with respect to the supply voltage.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nA 230 mHz inductor is connected in parallel with an 8 &amp;micro;F capacitor and a 330 &amp;Omega; resistor. Supply is 10 V with a frequency of 100 Hz. Calculate the branch currents, supply current and the phase angle of the supply current and the phase angle of the supply current with respect to the supply voltage.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 171      (318,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. In a circuit, the current is directly proportional to __________. &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. voltage &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. resistance&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. temperature &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 180      (353,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. Five volts is applied to two 2 ohm resistors in series. The resulting current is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. 5 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 2.5 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 1.25 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Not enough information is given.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Five volts is applied to two 2 ohm resistors connected in parallel. The resulting current is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. 5 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 2.5 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 1.25 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. 1 A&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Six volts is applied to a 2 ohm resistor in series with two 2 ohm resistors connected in parallel. The current through the first resistor is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. 3 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 2 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 1 A&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. .5 A&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. Which circuit law states that the sum of all currents into and out of a node equals zero? &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. Norton&#039;s Current Law.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Chebyshev&#039;s Current Law.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Kirchhoff&#039;s Current Law.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Lenz&#039;s Current Law.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. __________ carries negative charge and ____________ carries positive charge.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. proton, electron.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. electron, proton.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. neutron, electron.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6. In a circuit, the current is directly proportional to __________. &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;&quot;&gt;a. voltage &lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. resistance&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. temperature &lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 181      (423,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;1. When solar cells are connected in series, the&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. The voltages add up and the currents add up.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. The voltage remains the same and the currents add up.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. The currents add up and the voltage remains the same.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. The current remain the same and the voltage adds up.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;4&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;.&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;The photocurrent generated in a photovoltaic solar cell is&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. inversely proportional to the amount of solar radiation received.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. directly proportional the amount of solar radiation received.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. directly proportional to the square of the amount of solar radiation received.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. inversely proportional to the square of the amount of solar radiation received.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 182      (360,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. Solder will be composed of&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. 10% lead- 90% tin and cores of rosin &amp;quot;flux&amp;quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. 30% lead- 70% tin and cores of rosin &amp;quot;flux&amp;quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. 60% lead- 40% tin and cores of rosin &amp;quot;flux&amp;quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. 90% lead- 10% tin and cores of rosin &amp;quot;flux&amp;quot;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. The maximum number of rectangular components into which a vector can be resolved in its own plane is&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. Cleaning, Tinning, Heat &amp;amp; Solder, Cleaning&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Tinning, Cleaning, Heat &amp;amp; Solder, Cleaning&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Cleaning, Heat &amp;amp; Solder, Tinning, Cleaning&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. Heat &amp;amp; Solder, Cleaning, Tinning, Cleaning&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. For soldering more difficult metals which solder is best to use&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a.&amp;nbsp; Acid-core solder&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Rosin-core solder&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Both (a) and (b)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. None&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5. For Soldering electrical wiring which solder should be used&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a.&amp;nbsp; Acid-core solder&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. Rosin-core solder&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. Both (a) and (b)&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. None&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;6. Diameter of the rosin core solder for soldering electrical wiring should be&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. 1/4 inch&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. 1/2 inch&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. 1 inch&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. .032 inch&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;7. Lead-Free Soldering needs a higher temperature, about&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. 350 &amp;deg;C to 400 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. 250 &amp;deg;C to 400 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. 250 &amp;deg;C to 300 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. 150 &amp;deg;C to 200 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;8. Lead Based Soldering needs a higher temperature, about&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. 350 &amp;deg;C to 400 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;b. 250 &amp;deg;C to 400 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;c. 150 &amp;deg;C to 200 &amp;deg;C&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;d. 50 &amp;deg;C to 100 &amp;deg;C&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 185      (367,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. What is a slit?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. An obstacle&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. A rectangular opening&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. A&amp;nbsp; circular hole&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. All the above&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. When the path difference between the two light waves is integral multiples of &amp;lambda; then the waves are said to be ____________.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. Diffracted&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Interference of light.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4. A uniform intensity illumination.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. A pattern of zigzag variation.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;5.  186      (369,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. A diffraction grating has a slit separation of 1.6 &amp;times; 10-6 m.&amp;nbsp; When a parallel beam of light is incident normally on the grating, which of the wavelengths has a second order maximum at an angle of 32o to the direction of the incident beam?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. 210 nm&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. 420 nm&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. 550 nm&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. 840 nm&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2.  188      (376,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1.  189      (374,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;1. In Interference&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. There is loss of energy in great amount&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. There is no loss of energy&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. There is loss of energy in less amount&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. None of these&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;2. Which of the following light would produce an interference pattern with the largest separation between the bright fringes?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. Red&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Orange&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Green&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Blue&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;3. Two waves of same frequency and amplitude meet at a point where they are 180o out of phase.&amp;nbsp; Which of the following is correct?&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;a. They superimpose, resulting in zero intensity.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nb. Their amplitudes subtract, resulting in zero amplitude.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nc. Destructive interference occurs.&lt;br /&gt;\r\nd. Their energy at that point disappear and thus the energy of the waves after interference is half that of the original waves.&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;4.  190      (444,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;1. Which of the following statement is correct&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;a. All the above&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;4.  191      (446,'&lt;p class=&quot;contentTitleSmall&quot;&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;Assignment Questions&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/span&gt;&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p class=&quot;content&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-size: x-small&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana&quot;&gt;1.  192      (363,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana; &quot;&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/span&gt;&lt;a id=&quot;fck_paste_padding&quot;&gt;&lt;span style=&quot;font-family: Verdana;  195      (635,'&lt;p&gt;http://cite.iiit.ac.in/vlab/cITe/media/ccnsb/photoelectric.swf&lt;/p&gt;'),
 196      (628,'&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;\tLight is made up of photons. The energy of each photon is given by&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;http://cite.iiit.ac.in/vlab/cITe/images/ccnsb/pe4.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nwhere &lt;i&gt;h&lt;/i&gt; is the Plank&#039;s constant and &lt;i&gt;f&lt;/i&gt; is the frequency of photon.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nWhen a photon strikes a metal surface, some of its energy is transferred to the electron of the metal atom. It is called a photoelctron. Some of this energy is used by the photoelectron to break away from the metal surface and the rest is converted to its kinetic energy.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;http://cite.iiit.ac.in/vlab/cITe/images/ccnsb/pe1.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;http://cite.iiit.ac.in/vlab/cITe/images/ccnsb/pe2.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp; &amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&amp;nbsp;&lt;img alt=&quot;&quot; src=&quot;http://cite.iiit.ac.in/vlab/cITe/images/ccnsb/pe3.jpg&quot; /&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;br /&gt;\r\nwhere &amp;phi; is the work function characteristic to the metal and &lt;i&gt;f&lt;sub&gt;0&lt;/sub&gt;&lt;/i&gt; is the threshold frequency necessary for photocurrent.&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 197      (629,'&lt;ol&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Select a metal from the drop-down menu.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt; Set the intensity and the wavelength of the monochromatic light source. &lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;By varying the driving potential in the external circuit, find the stopping potential at which the current flow stops.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Repeat step 3 by varying the intensity and wavelength.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Calculate the work function of the selected metal from the value of stopping potential.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n    &lt;li&gt;&lt;strong&gt;Select the metal and go through steps 3-5.&lt;/strong&gt;&lt;/li&gt;\r\n&lt;/ol&gt;\r\n&lt;strong&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n&lt;/strong&gt;'),
 198      (638,'&lt;p&gt;this is a test&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 199      (645,'&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;This experient links to http://www.upscale.utoronto.ca/PVB/Harrison/Flash/#class_mech&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;table cellspacing=&quot;3&quot; cellpadding=&quot;3&quot; border=&quot;0&quot; align=&quot;center&quot;&gt;\r\n    &lt;tbody&gt;\r\n        &lt;tr&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;&lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/&quot;&gt;&lt;br /&gt;\r\n            &lt;/a&gt;&lt;/td&gt;\r\n            &lt;td&gt;\r\n            &lt;p&gt;This work is licensed under a &lt;a target=&quot;_blank&quot; href=&quot;http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/2.5/&quot;&gt;Creative             Commons License&lt;/a&gt;.&lt;/p&gt;\r\n            &lt;/td&gt;\r\n        &lt;/tr&gt;\r\n    &lt;/tbody&gt;\r\n&lt;/table&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=&quot;-1&quot;&gt;If you wish to put a copy of an animation on your own web server,    you may wish to know that in all cases the name of the animation file is the    same as the name of the html file that accesses it, except that the filename    extension is &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.swf&lt;/font&gt; instead of    &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.html&lt;/font&gt;. Thus from Netscape or Mozilla    you may use &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save As ... &lt;/font&gt;to save    the html file. Then you may manually change the URL so that it ends in &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.swf&lt;/font&gt;    instead of &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.html&lt;/font&gt;, press Enter    and use &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save As ...&lt;/font&gt; to  save the    swf file. Internet Explorer users will need to erase the entire file  name, so that the URL ends with the directory name: then after pressing  Enter the names of the files in the directory will be displayed and you  may right-click on the desired &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;swf&lt;/font&gt; file name and choose &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save Target As ...&lt;/font&gt;. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=&quot;-1&quot;&gt; I will be interested to know if you have downloaded one or more of my        animations; if you are so inclined send &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;'),
 200      (655,'&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;User blog for torsion pendulum&lt;/p&gt;'),
 201      (653,'&lt;p&gt;&amp;nbsp;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;h2&gt;AUTHOR, COPYRIGHT, COPYING&lt;/h2&gt;\r\n&lt;p&gt;&lt;font size=&quot;-1&quot;&gt;These animations were written by David M. Thus from Netscape or Mozilla    you may use &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save As ... &lt;/font&gt;to save    the html file. Then you may manually change the URL so that it ends in &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.swf&lt;/font&gt;    instead of &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;.html&lt;/font&gt;, press Enter    and use &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save As ...&lt;/font&gt;  to  save the    swf file. Internet Explorer users will need to erase  the entire file  name, so that the URL ends with the directory name:  then after pressing  Enter the names of the files in the directory will  be displayed and you  may right-click on the desired &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;swf&lt;/font&gt; file name and choose &lt;font face=&quot;Courier New, Courier, mono&quot;&gt;Save Target As ...&lt;/font&gt;. &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;\r\n&lt;font size=&quot;-1&quot;&gt; I will be interested to know if you have downloaded one or more of my        animations; if you are so inclined send &lt;/font&gt;'),
 202      (656,'&lt;p&gt;Test&lt;/p&gt;');
 203  UNLOCK TABLES;
 204  /*!40000 ALTER TABLE `avl_content_description` ENABLE KEYS*/;
 205  
 206  
 207  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `avl_content_details`;
 208  
 209  #
 210  # Table structure for table 'avl_content_details'
 211  #
 212  
 213  CREATE TABLE `avl_content_details` (
 214    `content_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
 215    `content_type_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 216    `experiment_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 217    `external` enum('Y','N') NOT NULL default 'Y',
 218    PRIMARY KEY  (`content_id`),
 219    UNIQUE KEY `content_id` (`content_id`)
 220  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=663 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
 221  
 222  
 223  
 224  #
 225  # Dumping data for table 'avl_content_details'
 226  #
 227  
 228  /*!40000 ALTER TABLE `avl_content_details` DISABLE KEYS*/;
 229  LOCK TABLES `avl_content_details` WRITE;

 696  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `avl_content_links`;
 697  
 698  #
 699  # Table structure for table 'avl_content_links'
 700  #
 701  
 702  CREATE TABLE `avl_content_links` (
 703    `content_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 704    `content_link` varchar(255) NOT NULL
 705  ) ENGINE=MyISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
 706  
 707  
 708

 710  # Dumping data for table 'avl_content_links'
 711  #

 753  
 754  
 755  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `avl_content_type_master`;
 756  
 757  #
 758  # Table structure for table 'avl_content_type_master'
 759  #
 760  
 761  CREATE TABLE `avl_content_type_master` (
 762    `content_type_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
 763    `content_type_name` varchar(100) NOT NULL,
 764    `type_mandatory` enum('Y','N') NOT NULL default 'N',
 765    PRIMARY KEY  (`content_type_id`),
 766    UNIQUE KEY `content_type_id` (`content_type_id`)
 767  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=19 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
 768  
 769  
 770  
 771  #
 772  # Dumping data for table 'avl_content_type_master'
 773  #
 774  
 775  /*!40000 ALTER TABLE `avl_content_type_master` DISABLE KEYS*/;
 776  LOCK TABLES `avl_content_type_master` WRITE;
 777  INSERT INTO `avl_content_type_master` (`content_type_id`, `content_type_name`, `type_mandatory`) VALUES (1,'Theory','Y'),

 780      (4,'Simulator','Y'),

 783      (7,'Feedback','Y'),

 789      (18,'User Blogs','N'),
 790      (16,'License','N');
 791  UNLOCK TABLES;
 792  /*!40000 ALTER TABLE `avl_content_type_master` ENABLE KEYS*/;
 793  
 794  
 795  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `avl_error_master`;
 796  
 797  #
 798  # Table structure for table 'avl_error_master'
 799  #
 800  
 801  CREATE TABLE `avl_error_master` (
 802    `error_sl_no` int(10) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
 803    `error_id` varchar(50) NOT NULL,
 804    `error_description` varchar(255) default NULL,
 805    PRIMARY KEY  (`error_sl_no`),
 806    UNIQUE KEY `error_sl_no` (`error_sl_no`,`error_id`),
 807    KEY `error_id` (`error_id`)
 808  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=76 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
 809

 899  # Table structure for table 'avl_experiment_branch_rel'
 900  #
 901  
 902  CREATE TABLE `avl_experiment_branch_rel` (
 903    `experiment_branch_rel_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
 904    `experiment_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 905    `branch_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 906    `academic_year_from` date default NULL,
 907    `academic_year_to` date default NULL,
 908    `experiment_branch_status` enum('A','D') NOT NULL default 'A',
 909    PRIMARY KEY  (`experiment_branch_rel_id`),
 910    UNIQUE KEY `experiment_branch_rel_id` (`experiment_branch_rel_id`)
 911  ) ENGINE=MyISAM DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

 927  #
 928  # Table structure for table 'avl_experiment_master'
 929  #
 930  
 931  CREATE TABLE `avl_experiment_master` (
 932    `experiment_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
 933    `experiment_name` varchar(100) NOT NULL,
 934    `experiment_description` varchar(255) default NULL,
 935    `experiment_type_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
 936    `experiment_status` enum('A','D') default 'A',
 937    `owner` int(5) unsigned default NULL,
 938    PRIMARY KEY  (`experiment_id`),
 939    UNIQUE KEY `experiment_id` (`experiment_id`)
 940  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=104 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

1277  #
1278  # Table structure for table 'avl_remote_trigger_schedule'
1279  #
1280  
1281  CREATE TABLE `avl_remote_trigger_schedule` (
1282    `job_id` int(50) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
1283    `equipment_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
1284    `user_email` varchar(255) default NULL,
1285    `start_time` timestamp NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
1286    `end_time` timestamp NOT NULL default '0000-00-00 00:00:00',
1287    `authorization_token` varchar(255) NOT NULL,
1288    `status` enum('R','S','F','E') NOT NULL,
1289    PRIMARY KEY  (`job_id`)
1290  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=5 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
1291

1609  DROP TABLE IF EXISTS `avl_university_master`;
1610  
1611  #
1612  # Table structure for table 'avl_university_master'
1613  #
1614  
1615  CREATE TABLE `avl_university_master` (
1616    `university_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
1617    `university_name` varchar(100) NOT NULL,
1618    `university_place` varchar(100) default NULL,
1619    `theme_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
1620    `url_of_site` varchar(255) NOT NULL,
1621    PRIMARY KEY  (`university_id`),
1622    UNIQUE KEY `university_id` (`university_id`)
1623  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=1001 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;

1644  
1645  CREATE TABLE `avl_user_master` (
1646    `user_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL auto_increment,
1647    `user_name` varchar(255) NOT NULL,
1648    `password` varchar(255) NOT NULL,
1649    `university_id` int(5) unsigned NOT NULL,
1650    `email_id` varchar(255) default NULL,
1651    PRIMARY KEY  (`user_id`),
1652    UNIQUE KEY `user_id` (`user_id`)
1653  ) ENGINE=MyISAM AUTO_INCREMENT=9 DEFAULT CHARSET=latin1;
